title: Data Analysis in Business (First edition)
text:
Welcome
This is a the website for ETF2121/5912 Handbook (1e). The handbook is a comprehensive guide to the ETF2121/5912 course, covering the course content and resources. The handbook is designed to be a valuable resource for students, providing them with the information they need to succeed in the course. In this book, you will find a practicum of skills for data analysis, including data manipulation, data visualization, and data modeling. The book is designed to be a practical guide, with hands-on exercises and examples to help you learn the skills you need to succeed in the course. The book is also designed to be a reference guide, with clear explanations and examples of the key concepts and techniques used in data analysis. The book is organized into chapters, each covering a specific topic in data analysis. Each chapter includes a summary of the key concepts, hands-on exercises, and examples to help you learn the material. The book also includes a glossary of key terms and concepts, as well as a list of additional resources for further reading. The book is designed to be used in conjunction with the ETF2121/5912 course, but it can also be used as a standalone resource for anyone interested in learning about data analysis. The book is suitable for students, professionals, and anyone interested in learning about data analysis and its applications. This book is solely authored by Dr.¬†Joan Tan and is affiliated with Monash University. The book is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License, which allows you to share and adapt the material for non-commercial purposes, as long as you give appropriate credit to the original authors and license your contributions under the same terms. All the mistakes are mine, and I welcome any feedback or suggestions for improvement. You can contact me at Joan Tan.
Yours sincerely,
Dr.¬†Joan Tan
Monash University
¬© 2026 Joan Tan. All rights reserved.

title: Course Structure
text:
Learning Objectives
This unit provides an overview of fundamental tools of data and statistical analysis used in the Business and Economics disciplines. The methods covered are widely used in industry and academia, providing the necessary foundation for more advanced approaches as you advance your training and career.
This course delves deeper into basic statistical concepts, with a focus on their application in finance, accounting, and other sectors. It introduces cutting-edge software and programming languages such as R, Power-BI, SQL and Excel for robust data analysis and predictive modelling. Students will engage with modern data sources and advanced sampling techniques, learn to perform hypothesis testing, and apply modelling techniques such as regression and time series analysis in business contexts. The course places a strong emphasis on practical applications, aiming to equip students with the skills to interpret and leverage statistical data for solving business problems and making informed decisions in industry.
This unit equips students with statistical techniques and the use of modern business software, including R, Excel, Power BI, for business applications. Students will learn to process and analyse extensive datasets using methods such as regression, time series analysis and classification. Key topics include modeling, regression analysis, and time series analysis in the business context.
On successful completion of this unit, you should be able to:

title: Course Structure
text:
Gain proficiency in business reporting tools and data analysis tool.
Learn to perform complex statistical analyses, including hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.
Use various predictive modeling technique to enhance forecasting and decision-making in business context.
Acquire skills to analyze and interpret real-time data for better business strategic planning and decision.

title: Course Structure
text:
Unit Outline

Section 1: Data Integration and Management.

Database Management System & Structured Query Language (SQL)
SQL Joins & Aggregation
Advanced SQL for Analytics



Section 2: Data Analysis and Statistical Modelling.

Descriptive Analytics and Data Wrangling
Data Visualisation
Data Aggregation and Sampling Methods
Regression Analysis
Predictive Analytics
Time Series Analysis



Section 3: Reporting and Storytelling.

Power BI Foundations
Power BI Dashboard
Course Review (Revision)

title: Course Structure
text:
Textbooks
The textbook for this course is just a supplement to the lectures and labs. The main resources for this course are the lecture notes, lab materials, and the course website. However, the following textbooks are recommended for additional reading:

Business Analytics by Camm, Cochran, Fry, Ohlmann, Anderson & Sweeney, 2024, 5th Edition.
Advanced Analytics with Power BI and R by Dr.¬†Leila Etaati, 2020.

title: Course Structure
text:
Assessment
The assessment for this unit is designed to evaluate your understanding of the course material and your ability to apply the concepts learned in practical scenarios. The assessment consists of the following components: - Quizzes: There will be a series of quizzes throughout the semester to test your understanding of the material covered in the lectures and readings. These quizzes will be conducted online and will consist of multiple-choice questions, short answer questions, and problem-solving exercises. The quizzes will be timed and will be available for a limited period. - Individual Assignments: You will be required to complete a series of individual assignments that will involve applying the concepts learned in the course to real-world scenarios. These assignments will require you to analyze data, interpret results, and present your findings in a clear and concise manner. The assignments will be submitted online and will be graded based on the quality of your analysis and presentation. - Group Project: You will be required to work in groups to complete a project that involves analyzing a dataset and presenting your findings. The project will require you to apply the concepts learned in the course to a real-world problem and will involve data collection, analysis, and presentation. The project will be graded based on the quality of your analysis, the effectiveness of your presentation, and your ability to work as a team. - Final Exam: The final exam will be a comprehensive assessment of the material covered in the course. The exam will consist of multiple-choice questions, short answer questions, and problem-solving exercises. The exam will be conducted in person and will be timed.

title: Course Structure
text:
Communication
All lecture notes, assignment instructions, an up-to-date schedule, and other course materials may be found on the course website or moodle page.
I will regularly send course announcements via Ed discussion board, make sure to check one or the other of these regularly. It is your responsibility to stay informed about the course progress and any changes to the schedule.

title: Course Structure
text:
Where to get help

If you have a question during lecture or tutorial, feel free to ask your teaching team or post your question in the discussion board. There are likely other students with the same question, and it is helpful to have the answer available to everyone.
The teaching team is here to help you be successful in the course. You are encouraged to attend the designated consultation hours to ask questions about the course content and assignments. Those consultation hours are available every day except weekend!
Outside of class and office hours, any general questions about course content or assignments should be posted on the Ed discussion board here. Please check whether your question has already been answered before posting. Please help each others by answering other questions, you will notice that you learn a lot by posting/responding to others. Do not expect the teaching team to answer questions that are posted during the weekend in the discussion board.
Emails should be reserved for personal questions that are not appropriate to be discuss in the forum. Please include ‚ÄúETF2121/5912‚Äù in the email subject line. Response time may be slower for emails with 24 hours being the maximum response time except weekend.

title: Course Structure
text:
Lectures and tutorials
Our goal in both lectures and labs is to encourage maximum interaction. As your instructor, I will introduce you to new tools and techniques, but it‚Äôs up to you to apply them effectively. Coding is best learned through practice, so much of our coursework will involve hands-on coding tasks. Each session will include various activities and assignments designed to enhance your skills.
Attendance and active participation in both lectures and tutorials are expected. Attending lectures and tutorials in person will provide the best learning experience. Some lectures will feature application exercises and periodic activities to foster a supportive learning community. These activities will be brief and enjoyable, aimed at strengthening connections among classmates throughout the semester.

Exams
Final exam. The exam will be held during the exam period, and it will be a closed-book exam with 5 pieces of A4 paper (10 pages) of handwritten/typed notes allowed. It is a supervised exam, and you will not be allowed to access the internet.


Software
All software used in this course can be downloaded for free. However, Power BI will not be available for Mac users, so I would encourage you to access it via MOVE. Please refer to this instruction.


Late work submission policy
Assignment deadlines are set to facilitate your progression through the course content and to enable timely feedback from the teaching team. I understand that unforeseen circumstances may occasionally arise, hindering your ability to meet a deadline. In such cases, you can request an extension through the Monash extension unit for extenuating circumstances. Please note that I do not grant individual approvals for late submissions, and requests should solely be made through the Monash extension unit.

There will be a 10% deduction for each 24-hour period the assignment is late.
If you submit an assessment task more than seven days after the due date, you‚Äôll receive a mark of zero and you won‚Äôt get any feedback.
Strictly no late submission without approval.
I will not reply to any email related to request on late submission.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
1.1 Introduction
A database management system (DBMS) is a software application that interacts with users, applications, and the database itself to capture and analyze data. A DBMS provides a systematic way to create, retrieve, update, and manage data. It allows users to define, create, maintain, and control access to the database.
Why databases are important?:

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
Data Storage: Databases provide a structured way to store large amounts of data efficiently.
Data Retrieval: They allow for quick and easy retrieval of data using queries.
Data Integrity: Databases enforce data integrity and consistency through constraints and rules.
Data Security: They provide mechanisms for securing data and controlling access to it.
Data Sharing: Databases enable multiple users to access and share data simultaneously.
Data Backup and Recovery: They provide tools for backing up data and recovering it in case of failure.
Data Relationships: Databases allow for the establishment of relationships between different data entities, enabling complex data modeling.
Data Analysis: They support advanced data analysis and reporting capabilities.
Data Scalability: Databases can handle large volumes of data and can be scaled to accommodate growth.
Data Transactions: They support transactions, ensuring that data operations are completed successfully or rolled back in case of failure.
Data Standards: Databases adhere to industry standards, making it easier to integrate with other systems and applications.
Data Performance: They optimize data access and retrieval for better performance.
Data Maintenance: Databases provide tools for maintaining data quality and consistency over time.
Data Auditing: They support auditing and tracking of data changes for compliance and accountability.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
section: 1.2 Why use a DBMS and not a spreadsheet/table?
text:
1.2 Why use a DBMS and not a spreadsheet/table?
Spreadsheets are great for small datasets and simple calculations, but they have limitations when it comes to handling large amounts of data, complex relationships, and multi-user access. A DBMS is designed to handle these challenges and provides a more robust solution for data management.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
1.3 Why not Excel?
Excel is a easy to use tool for data analysis and visualization, but it is not designed to be a full-fledged database management system. While Excel can be used for small datasets and simple calculations, a DBMS is a better choice for larger datasets and more complex data management needs. For example, in a large banking system, a DBMS would be used to manage customer accounts, transactions, and other data, while Excel might be used for simple reporting or analysis tasks. To deal with single large dataset, a DBMS is more efficient and effective than Excel. For example, a DBMS can handle millions of records and complex queries, while Excel may struggle with performance and data integrity issues. Also, when we need to joins multiple tables together, a DBMS provides powerful tools for managing relationships between tables, while Excel is limited in this regard. Imagine a bank store all the customers data in Excel, it would be very difficult to manage and retrieve the data efficiently. A DBMS would provide a more structured and efficient way to manage the data.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
section: 1.4 Difference between using DBMS and Excel
text:
1.4 Difference between using DBMS and Excel

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
1.5 What is Relational Database (RDBMS)?
A relational database is a type of database that organizes data into tables, which consist of rows and columns. Each table represents a specific entity or concept, and the columns represent the attributes or properties of that entity. The rows in the table represent individual records or instances of the entity. It allows for the establishment of relationships between different tables using keys, enabling complex data modeling and retrieval. Figure 1 illustrates a simple relational database with four tables: Drivers License, Member, Rental, Movie_Rental and Movie. Each table has its own set of columns and rows, and the relationships between the tables are established using primary and foreign keys. (we will cover keys later).



Figure 1: Simple Relational Database Example.


source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C3icLzBtg8I

title: 1¬† Database Management System
section: 1.6 What is the relationship between SQL vs.¬†RDBMS?
text:
1.6 What is the relationship between SQL vs.¬†RDBMS?
SQL (Structured Query Language) is a programming language used to manage and manipulate relational databases. It is the standard language for interacting with a RDBMS. SQL allows users to create, read, update, and delete data in a database. A RDBMS is the software that implements the database and provides the interface for users to interact with it using SQL.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
section: 1.7 Why SQL is important for a data analyst?
text:
1.7 Why SQL is important for a data analyst?
SQL is important because it provides a standardized way to interact with relational databases. It allows users to perform complex queries, retrieve data, and manipulate data in a consistent manner. SQL is widely used in the industry and is supported by most relational database management systems (RDBMS). Learning SQL is essential for anyone working with databases, as it enables them to effectively manage and analyze data. Additionally, SQL skills are highly sought after in the job market, making it a valuable asset for data analysts.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
2.1 What is SQL?
SQL (Structured Query Language) is a standard programming language used to manage and manipulate relational databases. It is used to perform various operations on the data stored in a database, such as querying, updating, inserting, and deleting data. SQL is widely used in the industry and is supported by most relational database management systems (RDBMS), including MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, and Microsoft SQL Server. The standard language for different RDBMS may have slight variations, but the core SQL syntax and functionality remain consistent across platforms. In this course, we will focus on using Oracle as our RDBMS. Oracle is chosen as it is widely used in the industry and provides a robust platform for learning SQL and database management concepts.
SQL is a declarative language, meaning that users specify what they want to do with the data, rather than how to do it. This allows for more efficient and optimized execution of queries by the database engine. SQL is also a powerful language that supports complex queries, joins, aggregations, and subqueries, making it suitable for a wide range of data analysis tasks.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
2.2 Basic SQL Commands
There are several types of SQL commands, each serving a different purpose. The main categories of SQL commands are:

Data Manipulation Language (DML): Used to manipulate data in the database.

Data Definition Language (DDL): Used to define and manage the structure of the database.

Data Query Language (DQL): Used to query and retrieve data from the database.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
2.3 Data Manipulation Language (DML)
DML commands are used to manipulate data in the database. They include commands for inserting, updating, deleting, and retrieving data.

INSERT: Used to add new rows of data to a table.
UPDATE: Used to modify existing data in a table.
DELETE: Used to remove rows of data from a table.


2.3.1 Data Definition Language (DDL)
DDL commands are used to define and manage the structure of the database. They include commands for creating, altering, and dropping database objects such as tables, indexes, and views.

CREATE: Used to create a new database object (e.g., table, index).
ALTER: Used to modify an existing database object (e.g., add or drop columns).
DROP: Used to delete an existing database object (e.g., table, index).
TRUNCATE: Used to delete all rows from a table without removing the table itself.
RENAME: Used to rename an existing database object (e.g., table, column).
COMMENT: Used to add comments to database objects (e.g., tables, columns).
CREATE INDEX: Used to create an index on a table to improve query performance.
DROP INDEX: Used to delete an existing index from a table.
CREATE VIEW: Used to create a virtual table based on the result of a query.
DROP VIEW: Used to delete an existing view from the database.
CREATE TABLE: Used to create a new table in the database.
ALTER TABLE: Used to modify the structure of an existing table (e.g., add or drop columns).
DROP TABLE: Used to delete an existing table from the database.

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
2.4 Data Query Language (DQL)
DQL commands are used to query and retrieve data from the database. The main DQL command is: - SELECT: Used to retrieve data from one or more tables in the database. - WHERE: Used to filter the results of a query based on specified conditions. - ORDER BY: Used to sort the results of a query in ascending or descending order - GROUP BY: Used to group the results of a query based on specified columns. - HAVING: Used to filter the results of a grouped query based on specified conditions - JOIN: Used to combine rows from two or more tables based on a related column between them. - UNION: Used to combine the results of two or more SELECT queries into a single result set. - DISTINCT: Used to retrieve unique values from a column, eliminating duplicate values. - LIMIT: Used to limit the number of rows returned by a query.
All these keywords will be explained in the next sections. üîÆ

title: 1¬† Database Management System
text:
2.5 Connecting to Oracle Database
For easy access and start, freesql is a free online SQL editor by Oracle that allows you to practice SQL queries without the need to install any software. You can sign up for a free account and start writing SQL queries right away.

2.5.1 How to sign up

Go to freesql.com.
Click on the ‚ÄúSign Up‚Äù button in the top right corner of the page.
Fill in the required information, including your name, email address, and password.
Click on the ‚ÄúCreate Account‚Äù button to complete the sign-up process.
Once you have created your account, you can log in to the platform and start using the SQL editor.



2.5.2 How to use FreeSQL

After logging in, you will be taken to the SQL editor page.
You can start writing SQL queries in the editor window.
To execute a query, click on the ‚ÄúRun‚Äù button or press ‚ÄúCtrl + Enter‚Äù on your keyboard.
The results of the query will be displayed in the results window
You can save your queries for future use by clicking on the ‚ÄúSave‚Äù button.

title: 2¬† SQL Basics
text:
2.1 Creating a Table
SQL follows a standard syntax for managing and manipulating relational databases. Below are some fundamental SQL commands and examples to help you get started.
The general structure of an SQL statement is as follows:
The select statement is used to retrieve data from a database, while the from clause specifies the table from which to retrieve the data. The where clause is optional and is used to filter the results based on a specified condition. These are SQL keywords and are not case-sensitive, but it is common practice to write them in uppercase for better readability. Also, they should end with a semicolon (;) to indicate the end of the statement.
To create a table in SQL, you can use the CREATE TABLE statement. Here is an example of how to create a simple table called Employees with columns for EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName, and HireDate:

title: 2¬† SQL Basics
2¬† SQL Basics
text:
2.2 Inserting Data
To insert data into a table, you can use the INSERT INTO statement. Here is an example of how to insert a new employee into the Employees table:
INSERT INTO Employees (EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName, HireDate)
VALUES (1, 'John', 'Doe', '2022-01-15');

title: 2¬† SQL Basics
2¬† SQL Basics
text:
2.4 Updating Data
To update existing data in a table, you can use the UPDATE statement. Here is an example of how to update the last name of an employee in the Employees table:
UPDATE Employees
SET LastName = 'Smith'
WHERE EmployeeID = 1;

title: 2¬† SQL Basics
text:
2.5 Deleting Data
To delete data from a table, you can use the DELETE statement. Here is an example of how to delete an employee from the Employees table:
DELETE FROM Employees
WHERE EmployeeID = 1;

2.5.0.1 Exercises

Create a table called Departments with columns for DepartmentID, DepartmentName, and Location.

CREATE TABLE Departments (
    DepartmentID INT PRIMARY KEY,
    DepartmentName VARCHAR(100),
    Location VARCHAR(100)
);

Insert three departments into the Departments table with appropriate values.

INSERT INTO Departments (DepartmentID, DepartmentName, Location)
VALUES
(1, 'Human Resources', 'Sydney'),
(2, 'Finance', 'Melbourne'),
(3, 'IT', 'Brisbane');

Write a query to select all departments located in ‚ÄòMelbourne‚Äô.

SELECT * FROM Departments
WHERE Location = 'Melbourne';

Update the location of department to ‚ÄòQueensland‚Äô.

UPDATE Departments
SET Location = 'Queensland'
WHERE DepartmentID = 3;

Delete a department with a specific DepartmentID.

DELETE FROM Departments
WHERE DepartmentID = 2;

title: 3¬† Introduction to R
text:
3.1 What is R?
R is a programming language and free software environment for statistical computing and graphics supported by the R Foundation for Statistical Computing. The R language is widely used among statisticians and data miners for developing statistical software and data analysis.

title: 3¬† Introduction to R
text:
3.2 Why R?

R is open-source and free
R is a powerful tool for data analysis
R has a large and active community
R has a large number of packages for data analysis
R is a great tool for reproducible research

title: 3¬† Introduction to R
text:
3.3 Posit (RStudio Desktop)
Posit (formerly RStudio) is an integrated development environment (IDE) for R. It includes a console, syntax-highlighting editor that supports direct code execution, as well as plotting (displaying graphs), history, debugging and workspace management tools.






Note‚ÄúR vs.¬†RStudio‚Äù



R is the programming language, while RStudio (now Posit) is an IDE that makes it easier to write and run R code. You can use R without RStudio, but RStudio provides a user-friendly interface and additional features that make working with R more efficient.

title: 3¬† Introduction to R
text:
3.4 Installing R and Posit (RStudio Desktop)

title: 3¬† Introduction to R
text:
3.5 Getting Started

title: Power BI
text:
Why Power BI?
Power BI is a powerful business intelligence tool that can handle large datasets and perform complex calculations quickly. It can connect to a wide variety of data sources, including databases, cloud services, and Excel files. The user-friendly interface allows users to create interactive reports and dashboards with ease. Additionally, Power BI enables the creation of custom visualizations and reports using DAX (Data Analysis Expressions) and M (Power Query Formula Language). With built-in collaboration features, users can easily share reports and dashboards with others, making it an ideal choice for organizations looking to enhance their data analysis capabilities.

title: Power BI
text:
Power BI vs.¬†Excel
Power BI and Excel are both powerful tools for data analysis, but they serve different purposes and have different strengths. Here are some key differences:

Data Handling: Power BI is designed to handle large datasets and can connect to a wide variety of data sources, while Excel is more suited for smaller datasets and manual data entry.
Data Visualization: Power BI offers a wide range of interactive visualizations and dashboards, while Excel has more limited charting capabilities.
Collaboration: Power BI allows for easy sharing and collaboration on reports and dashboards, while Excel requires more manual effort to share files.
Data Modeling: Power BI has advanced data modeling capabilities, including relationships between tables and DAX calculations, while Excel is more focused on spreadsheet calculations.
Real-time Data: Power BI can connect to real-time data sources, allowing for up-to-date reporting, while Excel requires manual updates.
Cost: Power BI has a subscription-based pricing model, while Excel is typically purchased as part of the Microsoft Office suite.




Power BI vs Excel

title: Power BI
text:
Power BI vs.¬†Tableau
Power BI and Tableau are both powerful data visualization tools, but they have some key differences:

Ease of Use: Power BI is generally considered more user-friendly, especially for those already familiar with Microsoft products. Tableau has a steeper learning curve but offers more advanced features for experienced users.
Data Handling: Power BI is better suited for handling large datasets and can connect to a wider variety of data sources, while Tableau is more focused on visualizations and may struggle with very large datasets.
Cost: Power BI is typically more affordable, with a subscription-based pricing model, while Tableau can be more expensive, especially for larger teams.
Collaboration: Power BI has built-in collaboration features that make it easy to share reports and dashboards, while Tableau requires more manual effort to share visualizations.
Customization: Tableau offers more customization options for visualizations, while Power BI has a more standardized set of visualizations.
Integration: Power BI integrates seamlessly with other Microsoft products, while Tableau has a wider range of third-party integrations.
Community and Support: Both tools have strong user communities and support resources, but Power BI has a larger user base due to its integration with Microsoft products.
